thread.title: Energy bills be gone: geoexchange heating, cooling technology tested in Perth
thread.title_full: Energy bills be gone: geoexchange heating, cooling technology tested in Perth

author: MARA FOX
title: Energy bills be gone: geoexchange heating, cooling technology tested in Perth
text:
AN innovative house design is hoped to blow a hole in heating and cooling bills with, well, a hole.
The new home in the Perth suburb of Craigie will sport a 60m deep hole as geoexchange technology is pitted against traditional heating and cooling.
Government developer LandCorp is spearheading the ‘Cool Earth’ project, where two homes will be built side by side in the suburb, which is 24km north of the CBD.
One home will sport the 150mm wide hole and testing over two years will compare traditional home heating and cooling against the sci-fi style geothermal variety.
LandCorp chief executive Frank Marra said geoexchange is essentially like a reverse cycle airconditioner.
“Except instead of air, it uses groundwater and the earth as the ‘heat sink’ — to remove the heat, or as the ‘heat source’ — to provide the heat,” he said.
A new home will have a 60m hole to test geothermal heating and cooling against traditional technologies. Source: Supplied
“Compared to standard airconditioners, geoexchange systems do not burn anywhere near as much fossil fuel.
“They simply transfer heat to and from the earth to provide a more affordable and environmentally friendly method of heating and cooling.
The geothermal system is already being used elsewhere around the globe, including the UK.
“This kind of technology is already being used around the world, generally for heating in cold climates, but it’s possible it could also be a more efficient, cost-effective and environmentally-friendly way for West Australians to keep cool in summer as well,” Mr Marra said.
The hole at The Vive estate property was dug this weekend and is one of LandCorp’s “innovation through demonstration” initiatives. Home designs at The Vive estate in Craigie. Source: Supplied
“We are building two homes side by side — one with the new technology and one without. This way, we can test the difference and measure the effectiveness of the technology, over a two-year period,” he said.
LandCorp is working together with several partners, including the Alcock Brown-Neaves Group, energy specialists Carbonomics, The University of WA and GeoExchange Australia.
The two houses to be used in the trial will be released as turnkey house and land packages in early 2016. The Vive at Craigie also includes a supported independent living facility designed specifically for younger adults with disabilities.
Originally published as Could this be the answer to high energy bills?
